## Public Member Typedefs

### GUID {#a3af0428ec6e48cb2f05c199b7b9f7e07}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>using llvm::GlobalValue::GUID =  uint64&#95;t</>}>
Declare a type to represent a global unique identifier for a global value.

This is a 64 bits hash that is used by PGO and ThinLTO to have a compact unique way to identify a symbol.

### canBeOmittedFromSymbolTable() {#ae3a42354a5b89aa8ade55dab229036f6}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool GlobalValue::canBeOmittedFromSymbolTable () const">
True if GV can be left out of the object symbol table.

This is the case for linkonce&#95;odr values whose address is not significant. While legal, it is not normally profitable to omit them from the .o symbol table. Using this analysis makes sense when the information can be passed down to the linker or we are in LTO.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h/#l00678">678</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h">GlobalValue.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/ir/globals-cpp/#l00425">425</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/ir/globals-cpp">Globals.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### hasAtLeastLocalUnnamedAddr() {#aaef9bedb9a16483f04717a57af933173}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool llvm::GlobalValue::hasAtLeastLocalUnnamedAddr () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Returns true if this value&#39;s address is not significant in this module.

This attribute is intended to be used only by the code generator and LTO to allow the linker to decide whether the global needs to be in the symbol table. It should probably not be used in optimizations, as the value may have uses outside the module; use <a href="#ac18f876b955434599bd93fd50aad53b8">hasGlobalUnnamedAddr()</a> instead.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h/#l00225">225</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h">GlobalValue.h</a>.

### isDefinitionExact() {#a008adb117253c7a0dde2f796be489d65}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool llvm::GlobalValue::isDefinitionExact () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Return true if the currently visible definition of this global (if any) is exactly the definition we will see at runtime.

Non-exact linkage types inhibits most non-inlining IPO, since a differently optimized variant of the same function can have different observable or undefined behavior than in the variant currently visible. For instance, we could have started with

void foo(int &#42;v) &#123; int t = 5 / v&#91;0&#93;; (void) t; &#125;

and &quot;refined&quot; it to

void foo(int &#42;v) &#123; &#125;

However, we cannot infer readnone for <code>foo</code>, since that would justify DSE&#39;ing a store to <code>v&#91;0&#93;</code> across a call to <code>foo</code>, which can cause undefined behavior if the linker replaces the actual call destination with the unoptimized <code>foo</code>.

Inlining is okay across non-exact linkage types as long as they&#39;re not interposable (see <code>isInterposable</code>), since in such cases the currently visible variant is <em>a</em> correct implementation of the original source function; it just isn&#39;t the <em>only</em> correct implementation.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h/#l00491">491</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h">GlobalValue.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool llvm::GlobalValue::isDiscardableIfUnused () const"
  labels = {["inline"]}>

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h/#l00549">549</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h">GlobalValue.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### isInterposable() {#aa1558e13ceef68db8ea9f4e3b5a64cbd}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool GlobalValue::isInterposable () const">
Return true if this global&#39;s definition can be substituted with an <em>arbitrary</em> definition at link time or load time.

We cannot do any IPO or inlining across interposable call edges, since the callee can be replaced with something arbitrary.

### isStrongDefinitionForLinker() {#a904b8b68c7e4e888158b03f0eae0e4d5}

Returns true if this global&#39;s definition will be the one chosen by the linker.

NB! Ideally this should not be used at the IR level at all. If you&#39;re interested in optimization constraints implied by the linker&#39;s ability to choose an implementation, prefer using <code>hasExactDefinition</code>.

### HasSanitizerMetadata {#a07e6feb9f188917f8dc965f78317f181}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned llvm::GlobalValue::HasSanitizerMetadata"
  labels = {["protected"]}>
True if this symbol has sanitizer metadata available.

Should only happen if sanitizers were enabled when building the translation unit which contains this GV.

<MemberDefinition

  labels = {["protected"]}>
The intrinsic <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/callingconv/#abdf8cf606905c10634e831390981b0ed">ID</a> for this subclass (which must be a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a>).

This member is defined by this class, but not used for anything. Subclasses can use it to store their intrinsic <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/callingconv/#abdf8cf606905c10634e831390981b0ed">ID</a>, if they have one.

This is stored here to save space in <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> on 64-bit hosts.

### dropLLVMManglingEscape() {#a3e999e4bb7297d284f931638721840e5}

If the given string begins with the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalvalue">GlobalValue</a> name mangling escape character &#39;\\1&#39;, drop it.

This function applies a specific mangling that is used in PGO profiles, among other things. If you&#39;re trying to get a symbol name for an arbitrary <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalvalue">GlobalValue</a>, this is not the function you&#39;re looking for; see <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/mangler-h">Mangler.h</a>.

<SectionDefinition>

## Materialization


Materialization is used to construct functions only as they&#39;re needed.

This is useful to reduce memory usage in LLVM or parsing work done by the BitcodeReader to load the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/module">Module</a>.

### isMaterializable {#ac010bf63f00b00f321a141448942a697}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool GlobalValue::isMaterializable () const">
If this function&#39;s <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/module">Module</a> is being lazily streamed in functions from disk or some other source, this method can be used to check to see if the function has been read in yet or not.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h/#l00608">608</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/globalvalue-h">GlobalValue.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/ir/globals-cpp/#l00043">43</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/ir/globals-cpp">Globals.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
